title: U.S. government looking for Huawei competitor in 5G, sources say
text:
Trump administration officials have reportedly discussed providing credit to Ericsson and Nokia so they can offer customer financing similar to that of the Chinese telecommunications equipment giant. Another Washington group encouraged Oracle and Cisco to launch radio-transmission products to compete against Huawei, but were turned down. (Financial Times)

Talking point: Washington has so far tried to limit the use of Huawei’s 5G equipment by threatening to stop sharing information with governments that allow it in their countries, and by cutting off the company’s access to American-made components. These new maneuvers are focused on the Chinese firm’s biggest advantage in the 5G equipment market: cost. Carriers have said its technology costs “tens of percents” less than its rivals. U.S. officials said the company can offer better prices and longer payment terms because it receives cheap credit from China’s state-owned banks. The Canadian federal government has also backed Huawei’s 5G rivals financially, though on R&D rather than customer financing. The Strategic Innovation Fund awarded Nokia $40 million in January to work on the technology, while in March 2018 it gave $66.7 million—matched by Ontario and Quebec—to Encqor, a project in which Ericsson is one of five large hardware leaders.
